elements.content: Using hydrothermal methods, a new series of five M(I)−Nb(V) oxyfluoride hybrid solids was prepared having the compositions [Cu(pyz)]2NbOF5 (1, pyz = pyrazine), Ag(pyz)NbOF4 (2), M(bpy)NbOF4·2H2O (3, M = Cu; 4, M = Ag; bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine), and [Cu(dpe)]2NbOF5·8H2O (5, dpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)-ethene). Each of the hybrid solids consists of layered structures with bridging ligands that coordinate via the Ag+ or Cu+ (i.e., M+) sites in each layer. The structure of 1 is comprised of [Cu2(pyz)2 2+] n double chains that are cross-linked into double layers by coordination to partially O/F-disordered [NbOF5]2− octahedra. Hybrids 2−4 contain pyz- and bpy-pillared [MNbOF4] layers, with the longer bpy ligand affording two interlayer water molecules per M+ site. These [MNbOF4] layers consist of ordered polar [NbOF4]− chains that are bridged via the M+ sites and that orient in alternating directions. The longest ligand in 5, dpe, results in a 3-fold interpenetrating pillared network consisting of [Cu(dpe)+] n chains bridged by O/F-disordered [NbOF5]2− octahedra and accommodating four interlayer water molecules per Cu+ site. The thermally-driven removal of water from 5 results in a loss of crystallinity, but which can be rapidly reversed by reabsorption of water. By contrast, the structures of 3 and 4 are retained upon dehydration, and both reversibly absorb either two waters or one methanol molecule per M+ site. Measured optical bandgap sizes for the Ag-containing hybrids occur at ∼3.13 eV and ∼3.54 eV for 2 and 4, and for the Cu-containing hybrids at ∼2.15 eV, ∼2.71 eV, and ∼2.30 eV for 1, 3, and 5, respectively. Dehydration of 3 and 4 results in a ∼0.3 eV red-shift of their bandgap sizes. Hybrids 2 and 4 are also found to be the first metal-oxyfluorides active for the photocatalytic decomposition of methylene blue with rates of 1.83 and 1.37 mg L−1 h−1, respectively.

elements.content: New Cu/Ag(I)−Nb(V) oxyfluoride hybrids were synthesized using a range of bridging ligands to give layered structures with increasing amounts of guest interlayer water. The two Ag-containing hybrids (shown) are photocatalytically active for the decomposition of methylene blue.
elements.clean_text: New Cu/Ag(I)-Nb(V) oxyfluoride hybrids were synthesized using a range of bridging ligands to give layered structures with increasing amounts of guest interlayer water. The two Ag-containing hybrids (shown) are photocatalytically active for the decomposition of methylene blue.

elements.content: The field of hybrid solids has rapidly expanded owing to the rich structural diversity achieved in modifying the structures of metal-oxides and -oxyfluorides with the use of organic ligands. One of the most common strategies is the selection for specific inorganic “building blocks” that are accessible in solution, such as metal-oxide clusters and layers, and that can be modified and cross-linked via coordination to a wide possible array of bridging ligands. Within metal-oxide structures, a range of important physical properties are found that have been the synthetic targets in many hybrids, including magnetism, ferroelectricity, microporosity, catalysis, as well as combinations. However, while many metal oxides are also currently intensely investigated for their ability to utilize solar energy to drive photocatalytic reactions, the properties and potential applications of hybrids in this area remain relatively unexplored.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The field of hybrid solids has rapidly expanded owing to the rich structural diversity achieved in modifying the structures of metal-oxides and -oxyfluorides with the use of organic ligands. One of the most common strategies is the selection for specific inorganic "building blocks" that are accessible in solution, such as metal-oxide clusters and layers, and that can be modified and cross-linked via coordination to a wide possible array of bridging ligands. Within metal-oxide structures, a range of important physical properties are found that have been the synthetic targets in many hybrids, including magnetism, ferroelectricity, microporosity, catalysis, as well as combinations. However, while many metal oxides are also currently intensely investigated for their ability to utilize solar energy to drive photocatalytic reactions, the properties and potential applications of hybrids in this area remain relatively unexplored.

elements.content: Our current research efforts have focused on hybrid solids containing a combination of d0 (e.g., Re7+, V5+) and d10 (e.g., Cu+, Ag+) transition metals, in order to investigate the structural and electronic origins of their low-energy light absorption and photocatalytic activity. For example, several condensed metal-oxides, such as Ag3VO4, Ag2MoO4, and AgNbO3, have been found to exhibit photocatalytic activities at close to visible-light energies. Recently, we have synthetically targeted hybrid versions of these condensed metal oxides in order to probe new ligand-modified forms containing controllable [−O−M−O−M−] n connectivities and dimensionalities. For example, “M n ReO4” or “M n VO3” (M = Cu+ or Ag+; n = 1 or 2) layers can be pillared by bridging ligands and yielding new hybrids such as M(pyz)ReO4 (M = Cu, Ag), M(pzc)2(H2O)2AgReO4 (M = Co, Ni), and Cu(pzc)2AgReO4. Also, the Cu(bpy)ReO4 and Cu(bpy)2ReO4·1/2H2O hybrids have been shown to exhibit ligand-mediated structural transformations that result in a significant modulation of their bandgap sizes within visible-light energies. The first discovery of photocatalytic activity for hybrids was recently reported in the related vanadate hybrids [Ag(L)]4V4O12·xH2O and Ag4(pzc)2V2O6. However, condensed niobium oxides represent some of the best known photocatalysts, and thus niobate hybrids represent a highly promising new direction to explore in this area.

elements.content: Niobium oxyfluorides have been investigated for their distorted Nb-centered octahedra that serve as convenient polar “building units” that can lead to noncentrosymmetric structures and properties. The two commonly found [Nb(O/F)6] n− octahedra include the isolated [NbOF5]2− and in O-bridged [NbOF4]− chains. The [NbOF4]− chains, constructed from trans-[NbO2/2F4] octahedra, have been found in MNbOF4 (M = NH4 + or alkali metal) but not yet in hybrids. These octahedra are bridged into a chain via their two trans-O atoms to give alternately shorter NbO and longer Nb−O bonds. By contrast, the [NbOF5]2− anion has previously been found in both condensed and hybrid solids. The distorted [NbOF5]2− octahedra exhibits an out-of-center displacement of the Nb atom towards the O ligand, forming a shorter NbO and longer trans Nb−F bond. Hydrothermal techniques have been used to prepare a number of hybrids containing [NbOF5]2− octahedra that are usually O/F-disordered and bridged by secondary metal cations into cluster or chain structures.

The two commonly found [Nb(O/F)6] n- octahedra include the isolated [NbOF5]2- and in O-bridged [NbOF4]- chains. The [NbOF4]- chains, constructed from trans-[NbO2/2F4] octahedra, have been found in MNbOF4 (M = NH4 + or alkali metal) but not yet in hybrids. These octahedra are bridged into a chain via their two trans-O atoms to give alternately shorter NbO and longer Nb-O bonds. By contrast, the [NbOF5]2- anion has previously been found in both condensed and hybrid solids. The distorted [NbOF5]2- octahedra exhibits an out-of-center displacement of the Nb atom towards the O ligand, forming a shorter NbO and longer trans Nb-F bond. Hydrothermal techniques have been used to prepare a number of hybrids containing [NbOF5]2- octahedra that are usually O/F-disordered and bridged by secondary metal cations into cluster or chain structures.

elements.content: Presented herein are the syntheses and characterization of layered niobium-oxyfluoride hybrids, [Cu(pyz)]2NbOF5 (1), Ag(pyz)NbOF4 (2), M(bpy)NbOF4·2H2O (3, M = Cu; 4, M = Ag), and [Cu(dpe)]2NbOF5·8H2O (5), and that contain [NbOF5]2− anions (1 and 5), as well as the first reported examples comprised of polar [NbOF4]− chains (2, 3, and 4). These new hybrids have been investigated for their thermal stability, absorption/desorption of methanol and water from within the interlayer spaces, and optical bandgap absorption and photocatalytic activity toward the decomposition of methylene blue.
elements.clean_text: Presented herein are the syntheses and characterization of layered niobium-oxyfluoride hybrids, [Cu(pyz)]2NbOF5 (1), Ag(pyz)NbOF4 (2), M(bpy)NbOF4⋅2H2O (3, M = Cu; 4, M = Ag), and [Cu(dpe)]2NbOF5⋅8H2O (5), and that contain [NbOF5]2- anions (1 and 5), as well as the first reported examples comprised of polar [NbOF4]- chains (2, 3, and 4). These new hybrids have been investigated for their thermal stability, absorption/desorption of methanol and water from within the interlayer spaces, and optical bandgap absorption and photocatalytic activity toward the decomposition of methylene blue.

elements.content: The syntheses of all hybrids were performed using hydrothermal conditions. Starting materials included Ag2O (99+%, Alfa Aesar), Cu2O (99%, Alfa Aesar), Nb2O5 (99.5%, Alfa Aesar), pyrazine (99+%, Aldrich), 4,4′-bipyridine (98%, Alfa Aesar), and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)-ethene (99%, Aldrich). All reactants were heat sealed inside an FEP Teflon pouch (American Durafilm; 3′′ × 4′′) that was placed inside a 125 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel and was backfilled with ∼40 mL of deionized water before closing. All reactions were heated inside a convection oven at 150 °C for 1−3 days and slowly cooled to room temperature at ∼6 °C·h−1. The products were recovered by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried in air. The crystallinity and phase purity of each compound were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) on an Inel XRG 3000 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation; λ = 1.5406 Å), given in the . The PXRD patterns were scanned over the range 2θ = 0−106° with a step size of 0.02°.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures and Materials

The syntheses of all hybrids were performed using hydrothermal conditions. Starting materials included Ag2O (99+%, Alfa Aesar), Cu2O (99%, Alfa Aesar), Nb2O5 (99.5%, Alfa Aesar), pyrazine (99+%, Aldrich), 4,4'-bipyridine (98%, Alfa Aesar), and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)-ethene (99%, Aldrich). All reactants were heat sealed inside an FEP Teflon pouch (American Durafilm; 3'' × 4'') that was placed inside a 125 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel and was backfilled with ~40 mL of deionized water before closing. All reactions were heated inside a convection oven at 150 °C for 1-3 days and slowly cooled to room temperature at ~6 °C⋅h-1. The products were recovered by filtration, washed with deionized water, and dried in air. The crystallinity and phase purity of each compound were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) on an Inel XRG 3000 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation; λ = 1.5406 Å), given in the . The PXRD patterns were scanned over the range 2θ = 0-106° with a step size of 0.02°.

elements.content: The synthesis of 1 was performed by mixing 61.1 mg (0.23 mmol) of Nb2O5, 32.9 mg (0.23 mol) of Cu2O, 36.8 mg (0.46 mmol) of pyrazine, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF, and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Orange-red crystals were obtained in ∼84% yield based on Cu. Compound 2 was synthesized by reacting 53.2 mg (0.20 mmol) of Nb2O5, 46.4 mg (0.20 mol) of Ag2O, 32.0 mg (0.40 mmol) of pyrazine, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF, and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Colorless-prism crystals were obtained in ∼47% yield based on Ag. Compound 3 was prepared by reacting 61.1 mg (0.23 mmol) of Nb2O5, 32.9 mg (0.23 mmol) of Cu2O, 71.8 mg (0.46 mmol) of bpy, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF, and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Greenish-yellow bar crystals were recovered in ∼66% yield based on Cu. The synthesis of 4 was performed by reacting 53.2 mg (0.20 mmol) of Nb2O5, 46.4 mg (0.20 mol) of Ag2O, 63.7 mg (0.40 mmol) of bpy, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Colorless prism-shaped crystals were recovered in ∼70% yield based on Ag. Compound 5 was prepared by reacting 20.0 mg (0.075 mmol) of Nb2O5, 21.5 mg (0.15 mmol) of Cu2O, 54.7 mg (0.30 mmol) of dpe, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Orange plate-shaped crystals were obtained in ∼70% yield based on Cu.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals were selected and mounted on a nylon loop with a small amount of NVH immersion oil. All single-crystal X-ray measurements were made on a Bruker-Nonius X8 Apex2 CCD diffractometer at 296 K using Mo Kα. radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The frame integrations were performed using the SAINT program. The resulting raw data were scaled and absorption corrected via a multiscan averaging of symmetry-equivalent data using the SADABS program. Each structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods within the Bruker SHELXTL-97 program package. Anisotropic thermal displacement parameters of all non-hydrogen atoms were allowed to refine. The phenyl hydrogen atoms were introduced at idealized positions and were allowed to ride on the parent carbon positions. The hydrogen atoms for water molecules were found in the residual electron density maps and constrained in the refinement. Further details of the data collections and structural refinements are summarized in Table . Selected interatomic distances and angles are listed in Table . Full details of the refinements can be found in the .

Crystallographic Structure Determination of 1-5 

Suitable single crystals were selected and mounted on a nylon loop with a small amount of NVH immersion oil. All single-crystal X-ray measurements were made on a Bruker-Nonius X8 Apex2 CCD diffractometer at 296 K using Mo Kα. radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The frame integrations were performed using the SAINT program. The resulting raw data were scaled and absorption corrected via a multiscan averaging of symmetry-equivalent data using the SADABS program. Each structure was solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods within the Bruker SHELXTL-97 program package. Anisotropic thermal displacement parameters of all non-hydrogen atoms were allowed to refine. The phenyl hydrogen atoms were introduced at idealized positions and were allowed to ride on the parent carbon positions. The hydrogen atoms for water molecules were found in the residual electron density maps and constrained in the refinement. Further details of the data collections and structural refinements are summarized in Table . Selected interatomic distances and angles are listed in Table . Full details of the refinements can be found in the .

UV−vis diffuse reflectance spectra of all compounds were measured on a Shimadzu UV-3600 UV−vis-NIR spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. Approximately 10 mg of powder of each sample was mounted onto a pressed BaSO4 powder holder and placed along the external window. A pressed BaSO4 powder was used as a reference, and the resulting data were plotted as the remission function F(R ∞) = (1 − R ∞)2/(2R ∞), where R is the diffuse reflectance based on the Kubelka-Monk theory of diffuse reflectance.
elements.clean_text:
Diffuse Reflectance Measurements

UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectra of all compounds were measured on a Shimadzu UV-3600 UV-vis-NIR spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere. Approximately 10 mg of powder of each sample was mounted onto a pressed BaSO4 powder holder and placed along the external window. A pressed BaSO4 powder was used as a reference, and the resulting data were plotted as the remission function F(R ∞) = (1 - R ∞)2/(2R ∞), where R is the diffuse reflectance based on the Kubelka-Monk theory of diffuse reflectance.

elements.content: The thermal stability and decomposition of the hybrids were measured on a TA Instruments TGA Q50 under flowing nitrogen gas while heating to 650 °C at a programmed rate of 5 °C/min. Weighed amounts (∼20 mg) of each compound were loaded onto Pt pans, equilibrated at room temperature, and the data were plotted as the starting weight (%) versus temperature (°C). Post-TGA residuals were characterized by PXRD (described above).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA)

The thermal stability and decomposition of the hybrids were measured on a TA Instruments TGA Q50 under flowing nitrogen gas while heating to 650 °C at a programmed rate of 5 °C/min. Weighed amounts (~20 mg) of each compound were loaded onto Pt pans, equilibrated at room temperature, and the data were plotted as the starting weight (%) versus temperature (°C). Post-TGA residuals were characterized by PXRD (described above).

elements.content: Methylene blue (MB) was used a model dye contaminant in order to evaluate the photocatalytic activities of each sample in the purification of dye wastewater. MB is reportedly difficult to degrade under visible light. The photocatalytic activity of each sample for the decomposition of MB followed previously described procedures. The photocatalytic activity was measured by suspending a weighed amount (150 mg) of the powdered samples in an aqueous solution of MB (6.0 mg/L, 50 mL) in an ∼60 mL cylindrical vessel. This mixture was stirred continuously under ultraviolet (λ < 400 nm) or visible-light (λ > 400 nm) irradiation using a 400 W high-pressure Xe arc lamp (focused through a shutter window). The Xe arc lamp was fitted with a water filter to remove infrared radiation and with cutoff filters to select for the desired wavelength ranges. The reactions were paused at ∼20 min intervals to determine the concentration of the aqueous MB solutions using a UV−vis spectrophotometer at λ = 655 nm.

Photocatalytic Reactions

elements.content: The structures and properties of a new series of Ag(I)/Cu(I)-niobium oxyfluoride hybrid solids have been systematically investigated using a series of three linear bridging ligands. The hybrid structures of 1−5 are described within separate sections below according to the length of the bridging ligand. All symmetry-unique atoms are labeled on at least one representative figure of each structure, and the distances for the open channels are labeled on the respective structures. These distances should be decreased by ∼1.5 Å for F and ∼1.7 Å for C in space-filling versions of these structures that would take into account the van der Waals radii. A listing of all near-neighbor interatomic distances can be found in Table together with a bond valence sum (BVS) analysis for each of the metal atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The structures and properties of a new series of Ag(I)/Cu(I)-niobium oxyfluoride hybrid solids have been systematically investigated using a series of three linear bridging ligands. The hybrid structures of 1-5 are described within separate sections below according to the length of the bridging ligand. All symmetry-unique atoms are labeled on at least one representative figure of each structure, and the distances for the open channels are labeled on the respective structures. These distances should be decreased by ~1.5 Å for F and ~1.7 Å for C in space-filling versions of these structures that would take into account the van der Waals radii. A listing of all near-neighbor interatomic distances can be found in Table  together with a bond valence sum (BVS) analysis for each of the metal atoms.

elements.content: The structure of 1 consists of one symmetry-unique [Cu2(pyz)2 2+] n double chain that is cross-linked into double layers by coordination to the [NbOF5]2− octahedra, as shown in Figure . Each Cu+ is coordinated to two F atoms from two neighboring [NbOF5]2− octahedra and to two N atoms on opposing pyrazine ligands above and below each chain, forming a distorted {CuF2N2} sawhorse coordination geometry. Two Cu+ sites share two common F atoms as a dimeric subunit, with a Cu−Cu distance of 3.2484(8) Å. These dimeric subunits form chains via coordination to the pyrazine ligands and which align face-to-face and run parallel to each other. Structurally similar dimeric subunits have been found in Cu(pyz)ReO4 and [Ag(L)]4V4O12·nH2O (L = 4,4′-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)-ethane) and shows similarly-spaced π−π stacking interactions.

elements.content: The single symmetry-unique [NbOF5]2− octahedron is nearly regular with the niobium site located on an inversion center. The Nb−O/F bond distances are consistent with other known niobium oxyfluorides and range from 1.903(3) to 1.931(3) Å. Bond-valence sum calculations (Table ) indicate the partial disorder of O on the terminal F1 site (valence of 0.91) compared to the equatorial F(2) or F(3) sites (valences of 0.76 and 0.75, respectively). The O/F-disordered [NbOF5]2− octahedra and [Cu2(pyz)2 2+] n dimers link together via the corner-sharing F2 site, forming linear chains that run along the b axis. Open spaces in the square net are relatively small at ∼2.8 × 4.8 Å2, marked in Figure B, and that form between the cross-linked [Cu2NbOF5] chains.

elements.content: Hybrid 2 is comprised of [AgNbOF4] layers that are stacked and bridged via coordination of the pyz ligands to the Ag+ sites in each layer, shown in Figure A. Each [AgNbOF4] layer, shown in Figure B, consists of two types of homoatomic chains. One type contains distorted [NbO2/2F4] octahedra that bridge via trans-vertex-shared O atoms, while the other type is comprised of chains of edge-shared and distorted {AgN2F4/2} octahedra. These two chains are connected via two of the equatorial F atoms in [NbO2/2F4] to four different Ag+ atoms within the layer. The layers are pillared via the pyrazine ligands, forming [Ag(pyz)] n + chains with a face-to-face orientation of the pyrazine ligands at ∼3.9 Å for a relatively weak π−π interaction. All Ag−F and Ag−N distances are in the typical range, shown in Table .

elements.content: Each niobium is in a slightly-distorted octahedral coordination geometry with four equatorial F atoms (Nb−F1, −F2, and −F3, at 1.89(1), 1.90(1), and 1.93(1) Å, respectively), and two trans-O atoms (Nb−O1 at 1.81(2) and 2.14(1) Å). As found in other [NbOF4]− layers, the shortest intraoctahedral bonds of ∼1.8 Å correspond to NbO, the next largest of ∼1.9 Å for Nb−F, and the longest of ∼2.1 Å for Nb−O. However, this type of [NbO2/2F4] chain has previously only been observed in condensed MNbOF4, for example, KNbOF4 and (NH4)NbOF4, and in Rb5Nb3OF18. Between neighboring [AgNbOF4] layers, the NbOF4 − octahedra are separated by ∼3.4 Å, forming relatively small open channels of ∼3.4 × 5.3 Å shown in Figure A.

elements.content: Shown in Figure , the structures of 3 and 4 are similar and contain [MNbOF4] layers (as described above for 2) that are pillared by the longer 4,4′-bipyridine ligand. Both 3 and 4 share comparable unit-cell dimensions and sizes, and so are here described together. The substitution of pyz for bpy results in significantly expanded interlayer spaces with open dimensions of ∼6.0 × 7.0 Å in 3 and ∼6.2 × 7.6 Å in 4, marked in Figure . The interlayer spaces are accessible and filled by two H2O molecules per formula that hydrogen bond to F atoms in the [MNbOF4] layers (O1w···F2, 2.86(6) Å in 3, and Ow···F, 2.74(2) Å in 4). The two main structural differences between 3 and 4 are in the stacking and flatness of the [MNbOF4] layers. In 3, the [CuNbOF4] layers stack directly on top of each other with the bpy ligands oriented perpendicular to the layers, while for 4 the [AgNbOF4] layers are shifted and the bpy ligands are slanted at an angle of ∼80.9° (Figure 1S in ). Further, the [CuNbOF4] layers in 3 are completely flat, while the [AgNbOF4] layers in 4 are slightly undulated, as shown by the M−Nb−M′−Nb′ torsion angles in Table .

elements.content: Shown in Figure , C and D, each [MNbOF4] layer consists of two types of homoatomic chains. One type consists of a vertex-shared chain of distorted [NbO2/2F4] octahedra and the other a chain of edge-shared and distorted {MN2F4/2} octahedra, as described above in 2. These two types of chains are connected via two of the equatorial F atoms in [NbO2/2F4] to four different M+ atoms within the layer. Each niobium is in a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry with four equatorial F atoms within a narrow Nb−F distance range of 1.914(3)−1.928(6) Å, and also with two trans-O atoms. Bonding to the trans-O atoms alternates between a shorter 1.725(7) Å and 1.728(9) Å for NbO, and a longer 2.107(7) and 2.082(9) Å for Nb−O, in 3 and 4, respectively. Within the chains, each Nb atom is shifted out of the basal plane of the octahedra by ∼0.382 Å in 3 and ∼0.354 Å in 4. These intraoctahedral distortions align down the chain in a polar fashion with neighboring chains facing opposing directions to cancel their dipole moments.

elements.content: The hybrid solid 5 exhibits a 3-fold interpenetrating framework (Schäfli symbol: {143}2{14}) constructed from [Cu(dpe)+] n chains that are linked by [NbOF5]2− octahedra, illustrated in Figure . Each Cu+ is coordinated to one F atom from [NbOF5]2− and to two N atoms from separate dpe ligands, to give a local T-shaped {CuN2F} coordination geometry. Each dpe ligand bridges between two Cu+ atoms to form a nearly linear [Cu(dpe)+] n chain with a N−Cu−N bond angle of 166.0(1)o. The [Cu(dpe)+] n chains are interconnected via coordination to the trans-F atoms of the [NbOF5]2− anions at positions alternately above and below each chain, shown in Figure B. However, the interlayer bridging between the [Cu(dpe)+] n chains in 5 is not coplanar and has a torsion angle of ∼24°. This network is 3-fold interpenetrating, shown in Figure D, and exhibits a stair-like framework similar to that known for [Ag(4,4′-bpy)]NO3. Despite the 3-fold interpenetration, the structure contains open channels with dimensions of ∼4.8 × 6.2 Å, and that are filled by eight guest H2O molecules per formula. All interatomic distances are otherwise within the typical ranges as reported for other metal-oxyfluoride hybrid structures containing chains or layers.

elements.content: Within the framework, all [NbOF5]2− octahedra are isolated from each other and exhibit a partial O/F-disorder over two of its vertices. Each Nb-centered octahedron is formed from four equatorial Nb−F distances of 1.941(11) Å ( × 2) and 1.969(10) Å ( × 2), and also to two axial Nb−O/F distances of 1.885(12) Å ( × 2). This last distance is intermediate between that typically found for NbO and a trans Nb−F distance (∼1.73 and ∼2.10 Å) in other niobium-oxyfluorides and in 1 above. Interestingly, the O/F disorder in the [NbOF5]2− octahedra results in the centrosymmetric space group Fddd rather than the polar space group Fdd2 that would align its polar direction down the c-axis. Trial structural refinements in Fdd2 did not result in alternately shorter NbO and longer Nb−F distances down the polar axis, and instead gave the intermediate Nb−O/F distance expected for O/F disorder.

elements.content: The thermal stabilities and structural loss of water and ligands were investigated for 1−5 by heating each sample to 650 °C under flowing N2. The TGA results for the hybrid solids are provided in Figure 5S in the . The pyz-containing hybrids, 1 and 2, show thermal stability up to a single major weight-loss step beginning at ∼250−275 °C, owing to the loss of pyrazine ligands as well as additional O or F atoms (43.6% and 33.1% for 1 and 2, respectively). Previous studies have shown that pyrazine may oxidize during liberation from a hybrid solid, and which accounts for the additional weight loss of O or F atoms from the hybrid solids and reduction of the post-TGA products. The post-TGA products were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to contain CuNb2O6 (#81046; ICDD) and CuO (#16025) for 1, and Ag and AgNbO3 for 2 (see ). Thus, the formation of CuO must have occurred via the reoxidation of Cu in the products, as shown by the subsequent ∼2.7% weight gain at ∼350−400 °C for 1. The TGA of 3−6 each exhibit multiple weight-loss steps owing to the removal of the structural water and ligands separately. Each loses all of its water content upon heating from ∼50−100 °C and exhibits a total weight loss that is consistent with their refined compositions (obsd/calc H2O content of 8.4%/8.2%, 7.3%/7.4%, and 16.2%/17.1% for 3, 4, and 5, respectively). A second weight-loss step occurs beginning at ∼300−350 °C for 3−5 and that corresponds to the complete loss of ligands and approximately two F or O atoms per formula (obsd/calc of 42.8%/44.1%, 41.7%/40.1%, and 50.5%/50.3% for 3, 4, and 5, respectively). As before, the post-TGA products were found by PXRD to contain a mixture of CuNb2O6 and CuO for 3 and 5, and a mixture of Ag (#44387) and AgNbO3 (#55647) for 4. Thus, the thermal stability of the hybrid frameworks increased upon going from the shorter pyz ligand (in 1 and 2), to the longer bpy and dpe ligands (in 3−5), each with a similar mixture of post-TGA products for either Cu (1, 3, and 5) or Ag (2 and 4).

elements.content: Hybrid solids 3, 4, and 5 each crystallize in a layered structure that contains guest water molecules that can be removed at low temperatures without the concomitant loss of ligands. The volume percentages occupied by the water molecules are calculated to be 12.0%, 13.2%, and 27.5%, respectively, using PLATON. As shown in the PXRD of Figure , hybrid solids 3 and 4 retain their crystalline structures after dehydration at 120 °C for 1 h, with a slight shift of the diffraction peaks to higher angles. Unfortunately, suitable single crystals of their dehydrated forms could not be found for a single-crystal XRD structure refinement. By contrast, most all of the intense PXRD peaks for 5 disappear, as shown in Figure 3S in the . Interestingly, the loss of guest water molecules was accompanied by a noticeable change in color from greenish-yellow to goldish-orange for 3 and from colorless to gray for 4.
elements.clean_text:
Desorption and Reabsorption of Water or Methanol

Hybrid solids 3, 4, and 5 each crystallize in a layered structure that contains guest water molecules that can be removed at low temperatures without the concomitant loss of ligands. The volume percentages occupied by the water molecules are calculated to be 12.0%, 13.2%, and 27.5%, respectively, using PLATON. As shown in the PXRD of Figure , hybrid solids 3 and 4 retain their crystalline structures after dehydration at 120 °C for 1 h, with a slight shift of the diffraction peaks to higher angles. Unfortunately, suitable single crystals of their dehydrated forms could not be found for a single-crystal XRD structure refinement. By contrast, most all of the intense PXRD peaks for 5 disappear, as shown in Figure 3S in the . Interestingly, the loss of guest water molecules was accompanied by a noticeable change in color from greenish-yellow to goldish-orange for 3 and from colorless to gray for 4.

elements.content: When dehydrated samples of 3 and 4 are exposed to either water or methanol solutions, their original colors returned within about one minute to greenish-yellow for 3 and colorless for 4. Their PXRD patterns are shown in Figure , and each still shows the characteristic diffraction patterns corresponding to their respective crystal structures. A TGA analysis of these water- and methanol-absorbed products, Figure , yielded weight losses corresponding to the removal of two waters per formula (calc/obsd of 7.1%/8.2% in 3 and 7.3%/7.4% in 4) and about one methanol per formula (calc/obsd of 6.9%/7.3% in 3 and 6.4/6.6% in 4). Further, both 3 and 4 can be cycled between their dehydrated and rehydrated forms, and between the methanol absorbed and desorbed forms. The IR spectrum for compound 4, Figure 6S in , shows the removal of the broad −OH stretching mode upon dehydration, and also, its re-emergence upon the absorption of water or methanol. The relative ease of small-molecule absorption likely is due to favorable hydrogen bonding interactions of both water and methanol to the interlayer F atoms on the octahedral [NbOF4]− chains, that is, forming OH2···F or MeOH···F hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: A similar dehydration and rehydration of the 3-fold interpenetrating structure of 5 was investigated. However, the low-temperature removal of its greater water content (120 °C for 1−3 h) is accompanied by the loss of crystallinity of its structure, as found by PXRD (Figure S in the ). Only a few very weak and broad diffraction peaks were observed that could not be assigned. Also, the crystal habit changed from transparent orange platelets to opaque blackish-orange platelets that exhibited a high amount of cracks. Interestingly, these dehydrated samples can be fully rehydrated by immersing in an aqueous solution for several hours. Their color returns to greenish-orange and the PXRD patterns are nearly identical to that for the originally synthesized samples. Thus, the hybrid structure of 5 easily recrystallizes at room temperature in an aqueous solution.

elements.content: Heterometallic hybrid solids containing transition metals combining a d10 (e.g., Cu+, Ag+) and a d0 (e.g., Nb5+, Mo6+, Re7+) electron configuration have drawn increasing attention owing to their potentially low-energy visible-light absorptions that arise from a metal-to-metal charger transfer (MMCT) transition. The series of M(I)−Nb oxyfluoride hybrids in 1−5 exhibits colors varying from colorless to orangish-red. Thus, their diffuse reflectance spectra for each were measured in order to probe the influence of the late transition-metal (i.e., Ag+ versus Cu+), the bridging ligands, and the water content on their optical bandgap sizes.
elements.clean_text:
Optical Properties

Heterometallic hybrid solids containing transition metals combining a d10 (e.g., Cu+, Ag+) and a d0 (e.g., Nb5+, Mo6+, Re7+) electron configuration have drawn increasing attention owing to their potentially low-energy visible-light absorptions that arise from a metal-to-metal charger transfer (MMCT) transition. The series of M(I)-Nb oxyfluoride hybrids in 1-5 exhibits colors varying from colorless to orangish-red. Thus, their diffuse reflectance spectra for each were measured in order to probe the influence of the late transition-metal (i.e., Ag+ versus Cu+), the bridging ligands, and the water content on their optical bandgap sizes.

elements.content: Shown in Figure , the onset of the optical absorption edges for the Ag-containing hybrid solids, 2 and 4, occur at ultraviolet energies with estimated bandgap sizes of ∼3.13 and ∼3.54 eV, respectively. By contrast, absorption edges for the Cu-containing hybrids, 1, 3, and 5, were generally positioned in the lower-energy visible-light energies with estimated bandgap sizes of ∼2.15, ∼2.71, and ∼2.30 eV, respectively. The substitution of Ag+ for Cu+ is expected to shift the optical absorption strongly into the visible region owing to the replacement of lower-energy d orbitals of Ag+ for the higher-energy d orbitals of Cu+, as described before. Thus, the bandgap sizes of the Cu-containing hybrids are ∼1−1.2 eV smaller than their Ag-containing analogues, that is, in 1 versus 2, or in 3 versus 4.

Thus, the bandgap sizes of the Cu-containing hybrids are ~1-1.2 eV smaller than their Ag-containing analogues, that is, in 1 versus 2, or in 3 versus 4.

elements.content: The condensed MNbO3 solids (M = Ag+, Cu+) show a similar trend in bandgap sizes, at ∼2.9 eV for AgNbO3 and ∼2.1 eV for CuNbO3. Pyrazine-containing hybrids 1 and 2 each exhibit bandgap sizes close to that of the ligand-free MNbO3 solids, showing that the pyz π/π* orbitals must fall outside the bandgap region and otherwise have little effect on the bandgap size. As expected for an electronic transition primarily involving the two metal centers, that is, a MMCT transition, the incorporation of F into the metal-oxide structure also has had little discernible effect on their bandgap sizes. However, substitution pyz for bpy in 3 and 4 results in an ∼0.4−0.6 eV blue-shift of their optical absorption edges compared to 1 and 2, respectively. The bandgap sizes of 3 and 4 can be red-shifted by ∼0.3 eV upon removing the guest water molecules in the structure, shown in Figure B. The bandgap size of 3 is decreased to ∼2.39 eV while that for 4 is decreased to ∼3.24 eV. Surprisingly, the interlayer waters in the structures of 3 and 4 play a significant factor in increasing their bandgap sizes compared to the pyz-based hybrids. Hydrogen-bonding interactions to the [M(bpy)NbOF4] layers must act to modify their atomic and electronic structures. In contrast, hybrid solid 5 has a higher water content but exhibits a smaller bandgap size.

elements.content: A dye molecule that is often used to represent the common contaminants in textile effluents is methylene blue (MB). MB is typically difficult to decompose in wastewater streams, and thus was selected in order to investigate the photocatalytic activities of the new hybrid solids toward the decomposition of organic pollutants. Only three hybrid solids, all of them silver-vanadates, have been investigated for this reaction and found to be active. However, the activity of metal-oxyfluoride hybrids is entirely unexplored. Concentration changes of the aqueous MB solutions were plotted versus irradiation time, shown in Figure . Simple photolysis of the MB solution, that is, in the absence of a hybrid solid, was measured as a control. There is a slightly faster apparent rate during the first 20 min owing to the adsorption of MB to the particle surfaces and that was not included in the rate calculations. Further, this effect increased with the amount of hybrid solid used.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Decomposition Reactions

A dye molecule that is often used to represent the common contaminants in textile effluents is methylene blue (MB). MB is typically difficult to decompose in wastewater streams, and thus was selected in order to investigate the photocatalytic activities of the new hybrid solids toward the decomposition of organic pollutants. Only three hybrid solids, all of them silver-vanadates, have been investigated for this reaction and found to be active. However, the activity of metal-oxyfluoride hybrids is entirely unexplored. Concentration changes of the aqueous MB solutions were plotted versus irradiation time, shown in Figure . Simple photolysis of the MB solution, that is, in the absence of a hybrid solid, was measured as a control. There is a slightly faster apparent rate during the first 20 min owing to the adsorption of MB to the particle surfaces and that was not included in the rate calculations. Further, this effect increased with the amount of hybrid solid used.

elements.clean_text: 8  Plots of the photocatalytic decomposition of MB solutions (C 0 = 6.0 mg/L; total 50 mL) using 150 mg of 2 (a) and 4 (b) under UV light irradiation. Simple photolysis of the ligand alone is labeled (c).

elements.content: Both of the Ag-containing hybrids, 2 and 4, were found to be photocatalytically active under ultraviolet light, with corresponding rates of 1.83 and 1.37 mg L−1 h−1, respectively. These rates fall within a similar range as found for the hybrid vanadates, but with higher rates for the more extended metal-oxide and -oxyfluoride networks. After 2 h of irradiation, approximately 65% and 45% of MB has been decomposed using of 150 mg of 2 and 4, respectively. However, the Cu-containing hybrids 1, 3, and 5, with lower-energy bandgap sizes, were not active either under visible or ultraviolet light. The Cu-containing hybrids have higher-energy valence bands, owing to the different energies of the 3d10 versus 4d10 orbitals, and thus a reduced oxidizing strength upon photoexcitation. The presence of Ag in the hybrid framework appears to be critical for photocatalytic activity toward the decomposition of MB or potentially other organic pollutants.

These rates fall within a similar range as found for the hybrid vanadates, but with higher rates for the more extended metal-oxide and -oxyfluoride networks. After 2 h of irradiation, approximately 65% and 45% of MB has been decomposed using of 150 mg of 2 and 4, respectively. However, the Cu-containing hybrids 1, 3, and 5, with lower-energy bandgap sizes, were not active either under visible or ultraviolet light. The Cu-containing hybrids have higher-energy valence bands, owing to the different energies of the 3d10 versus 4d10 orbitals, and thus a reduced oxidizing strength upon photoexcitation. The presence of Ag in the hybrid framework appears to be critical for photocatalytic activity toward the decomposition of MB or potentially other organic pollutants.

elements.content: Three different bridging ligands, pyz, bpy, and dpe, were used to investigate new structure and property modifications possible by varying the ligand length in copper- and silver-niobate oxyfluorides. The structure of 1 contains layers of [Cu2(pyz)2 2+] n double chains that are cross-linked into double layers by coordination to the O/F-disordered [NbOF5]2− anions. The structures of 2−4 contain [MNbOF4] (M = Ag or Cu) layers constructed from ordered polar [NbOF4]− chains and that are pillared by either pyz or bpy ligands. Hybrid 5 has a 3-fold interpenetrating framework consisting of [Cu(dpe)+] n chains that are linked by coordination to O/F-disordered [NbOF5]2− anions. Each of the bridging ligands results in a layered or pillared structure that accommodates an increasing amount of interlayer water from 0 for pyz, to 2 for bpy, and up to 8 for dpe. The structures of 3 and 4 can be dehydrated without a loss of their crystallinities. Both can also reabsorb up to about two water molecules or one methanol molecule per formula at room temperature. The solids either exhibit bandgap sizes at ultraviolet energies for the Ag-containing hybrids or visible-light energies for the Cu-containing hybrids. Further, the Ag-containing hybrids are photocatalytically active for the decomposition of MB in aqueous solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three different bridging ligands, pyz, bpy, and dpe, were used to investigate new structure and property modifications possible by varying the ligand length in copper- and silver-niobate oxyfluorides. The structure of 1 contains layers of [Cu2(pyz)2 2+] n  double chains that are cross-linked into double layers by coordination to the O/F-disordered [NbOF5]2- anions. The structures of 2-4 contain [MNbOF4] (M = Ag or Cu) layers constructed from ordered polar [NbOF4]- chains and that are pillared by either pyz or bpy ligands. Hybrid 5 has a 3-fold interpenetrating framework consisting of [Cu(dpe)+] n  chains that are linked by coordination to O/F-disordered [NbOF5]2- anions. Each of the bridging ligands results in a layered or pillared structure that accommodates an increasing amount of interlayer water from 0 for pyz, to 2 for bpy, and up to 8 for dpe. The structures of 3 and 4 can be dehydrated without a loss of their crystallinities. Both can also reabsorb up to about two water molecules or one methanol molecule per formula at room temperature. The solids either exhibit bandgap sizes at ultraviolet energies for the Ag-containing hybrids or visible-light energies for the Cu-containing hybrids. Further, the Ag-containing hybrids are photocatalytically active for the decomposition of MB in aqueous solutions.

cln_elements.content: The synthesis of 1 was performed by mixing 61.1 mg (0.23 mmol) of Nb2O5, 32.9 mg (0.23 mol) of Cu2O, 36.8 mg (0.46 mmol) of pyrazine, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF, and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Orange-red crystals were obtained in ∼84% yield based on Cu. Compound 2 was synthesized by reacting 53.2 mg (0.20 mmol) of Nb2O5, 46.4 mg (0.20 mol) of Ag2O, 32.0 mg (0.40 mmol) of pyrazine, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF, and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Colorless-prism crystals were obtained in ∼47% yield based on Ag. Compound 3 was prepared by reacting 61.1 mg (0.23 mmol) of Nb2O5, 32.9 mg (0.23 mmol) of Cu2O, 71.8 mg (0.46 mmol) of bpy, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF, and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Greenish-yellow bar crystals were recovered in ∼66% yield based on Cu. The synthesis of 4 was performed by reacting 53.2 mg (0.20 mmol) of Nb2O5, 46.4 mg (0.20 mol) of Ag2O, 63.7 mg (0.40 mmol) of bpy, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Colorless prism-shaped crystals were recovered in ∼70% yield based on Ag. Compound 5 was prepared by reacting 20.0 mg (0.075 mmol) of Nb2O5, 21.5 mg (0.15 mmol) of Cu2O, 54.7 mg (0.30 mmol) of dpe, 0.188 g (4.6 mmol) of 49% aqueous HF and 0.400 g (22.2 mmol) of deionized H2O. Orange plate-shaped crystals were obtained in ∼70% yield based on Cu.

cln_elements.content: The thermal stabilities and structural loss of water and ligands were investigated for 1−5 by heating each sample to 650 °C under flowing N2. The TGA results for the hybrid solids are provided in Figure 5S in the . The pyz-containing hybrids, 1 and 2, show thermal stability up to a single major weight-loss step beginning at ∼250−275 °C, owing to the loss of pyrazine ligands as well as additional O or F atoms (43.6% and 33.1% for 1 and 2, respectively). Previous studies have shown that pyrazine may oxidize during liberation from a hybrid solid, and which accounts for the additional weight loss of O or F atoms from the hybrid solids and reduction of the post-TGA products. The post-TGA products were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to contain CuNb2O6 (#81046; ICDD) and CuO (#16025) for 1, and Ag and AgNbO3 for 2 (see ). Thus, the formation of CuO must have occurred via the reoxidation of Cu in the products, as shown by the subsequent ∼2.7% weight gain at ∼350−400 °C for 1. The TGA of 3−6 each exhibit multiple weight-loss steps owing to the removal of the structural water and ligands separately. Each loses all of its water content upon heating from ∼50−100 °C and exhibits a total weight loss that is consistent with their refined compositions (obsd/calc H2O content of 8.4%/8.2%, 7.3%/7.4%, and 16.2%/17.1% for 3, 4, and 5, respectively). A second weight-loss step occurs beginning at ∼300−350 °C for 3−5 and that corresponds to the complete loss of ligands and approximately two F or O atoms per formula (obsd/calc of 42.8%/44.1%, 41.7%/40.1%, and 50.5%/50.3% for 3, 4, and 5, respectively). As before, the post-TGA products were found by PXRD to contain a mixture of CuNb2O6 and CuO for 3 and 5, and a mixture of Ag (#44387) and AgNbO3 (#55647) for 4. Thus, the thermal stability of the hybrid frameworks increased upon going from the shorter pyz ligand (in 1 and 2), to the longer bpy and dpe ligands (in 3−5), each with a similar mixture of post-TGA products for either Cu (1, 3, and 5) or Ag (2 and 4).

Thermogravimetric Analyses (TGA)

The thermal stabilities and structural loss of water and ligands were investigated for 1-5 by heating each sample to 650 °C under flowing N2. The TGA results for the hybrid solids are provided in Figure 5S in the . The pyz-containing hybrids, 1 and 2, show thermal stability up to a single major weight-loss step beginning at ~250-275 °C, owing to the loss of pyrazine ligands as well as additional O or F atoms (43.6% and 33.1% for 1 and 2, respectively). Previous studies have shown that pyrazine may oxidize during liberation from a hybrid solid, and which accounts for the additional weight loss of O or F atoms from the hybrid solids and reduction of the post-TGA products. The post-TGA products were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to contain CuNb2O6 (#81046; ICDD) and CuO (#16025) for 1, and Ag and AgNbO3 for 2 (see ). Thus, the formation of CuO must have occurred via the reoxidation of Cu in the products, as shown by the subsequent ~2.7% weight gain at ~350-400 °C for 1. The TGA of 3-6 each exhibit multiple weight-loss steps owing to the removal of the structural water and ligands separately. Each loses all of its water content upon heating from ~50-100 °C and exhibits a total weight loss that is consistent with their refined compositions (obsd/calc H2O content of 8.4%/8.2%, 7.3%/7.4%, and 16.2%/17.1% for 3, 4, and 5, respectively). A second weight-loss step occurs beginning at ~300-350 °C for 3-5 and that corresponds to the complete loss of ligands and approximately two F or O atoms per formula (obsd/calc of 42.8%/44.1%, 41.7%/40.1%, and 50.5%/50.3% for 3, 4, and 5, respectively). As before, the post-TGA products were found by PXRD to contain a mixture of CuNb2O6 and CuO for 3 and 5, and a mixture of Ag (#44387) and AgNbO3 (#55647) for 4. Thus, the thermal stability of the hybrid frameworks increased upon going from the shorter pyz ligand (in 1 and 2), to the longer bpy and dpe ligands (in 3-5), each with a similar mixture of post-TGA products for either Cu (1, 3, and 5) or Ag (2 and 4).
